stream_context.summary: Kaze works on polishing a late-game "casino/arcade/space" level for the upcoming RTYI demo, fixing visual bugs, adding teleport pads, low-gravity zones, lighting and carpet textures while testing performance and discussing future release/monetisation ideas.

development_findings.summary: The public demo is “mostly ready”; Kaze fixed visual bugs off-stream and is now finishing Course 15 plus overworld and 2–5 small side levels. He will not release at Christmas to avoid clashing with another project.
development_findings.quote: I was getting the demo mostly release ready off stream… I don’t want to ruin Robot’s release.

development_findings.summary: Worst-case framerate in the new level is 22–25 FPS; Kaze deems this acceptable for N64 and plans to cap at 30 FPS for smoother perception.
development_findings.quote: Limited FPS actually runs better… The absolute worst FPS you can get in this level is… 22 to 25. I think this is fine.

development_findings.summary: Implemented ‘warp platforms’: standing still makes Mario spin, shrink, gain underside lighting and teleport. Transparency was avoided by scaling Mario’s matrix instead of fading.
development_findings.quote: I want them to be… distorting, spinning, big-animation warps… applying scale animation where Mario just scales into the ground.

development_findings.summary: Added configurable low-gravity zones using a simple collision flag; visually marked by blue translucent planes.
development_findings.quote: Now we just need to add the low gravity part … Low gravity’s on. It’s as simple as that.

development_findings.summary: Created a materialising bridge with scrolling textures and colour-shift fade-out; bug-hunted alpha issues across emulators.
development_findings.quote: Look at this. It slowly changes colour, turns dark and disappears. Oh my God, that looks so good.

development_findings.summary: Decided to replace remaining Nintendo library code because it is inefficient; aims to strip 64-bit instructions so the engine is purely 32-bit.
development_findings.quote: This code here was literally twice as many cycles… I am planning to replace it, not even for legal reasons— the code is complete dog ass.

development_findings.summary: Considering dual release: RTYI as a free Mario hack and a 90 % identical, fully original IP reskin (new protagonist, tweaked movement) sold on Steam using Wiseguy’s Recomp.
development_findings.quote: What if… I also release a game that is 90 % the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own?

development_findings.summary: Design workflow: outline desired mechanics, program required actors, scatter them, play-test, keep fun parts, discard the rest, then polish.
development_findings.quote: Then I just start moving it around and see what’s fun and what isn’t… and then we polish it up.

development_findings.summary: Uses Fast64 plugin; targets 60 FPS on Steam Deck; final ROM will fill the full 64 MB.
development_findings.quote: If I have 64 megabytes I can use all of them… 60 on Steam Deck is a good target.

development_findings.summary: Brainstormed decorative CRTs with animated GIFs and neon rings to reinforce arcade aesthetic.

context_findings.summary: Kaze debates cultural norms of greeting, expressing discomfort with ‘Hello, how are you?’ small talk.
context_findings.quote: You’re being a weirdo, requesting information like that. Like, what does it matter to you how I am?

context_findings.summary: He is monitoring Kickstarter trends; surprised by $18 k raised on 74 backers and sees personalised NPC tiers as ‘OP strategy’.
context_findings.quote: The average person is dropping $250 on this? This is insane data. I need to keep this in mind.

context_findings.summary: Legal awareness: cannot make physical carts without Nintendo rights; wonders if Nintendo would audit his Steam code.
context_findings.quote: To make a physical cart, I would need the rights to Super Mario 64… Do you think Nintendo is going to hire programmers to look at my source code?

context_findings.summary: Personal notes: will celebrate with in-laws and watch Sonic 3 tomorrow; references marriage to Zeina casually during stream.
Expresses frustration and humour when debugging, but shows clear excitement when visual effects work.
context_findings.quote: That looks perfect… Oh my God, that looks so good.

biobak.summary: Currently reworking most of Kaze’s textures/art, so Kaze is trying not to over-polish placeholders.
biobak.quote: I probably shouldn’t spend so much time on textures… considering Biobak is reworking all my stuff anyway.

zeina.summary: Created the new carpet texture for the casino level, which Kaze and chat praise.
zeina.quote: What do you think of the carpet that Zeina made? … I like it a lot.

zeina.summary: Supports stream, subbed for 47 months; casual on-stream banter shows comfortable working/marriage dynamic.

key_stories.title: Purging Nintendo’s Inefficient Code
key_stories.summary: While profiling engine routines, Kaze discovers Nintendo’s original cache functions waste half their CPU cycles. He decides to rewrite or delete all remaining proprietary code, partly for performance and partly to avoid legal grey areas.
key_stories.challenge: Original SM64 kernel routines are slow and legally murky.
key_stories.process: Read assembly, measured cycles, compared to rewritten version, explained inefficiencies on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Plans full replacement with custom 32-bit-only codebase.
key_stories.key_quote: Why was there 50 % inefficiency in four lines of code? I am planning to replace it—the code is complete dog ass.

key_stories.title: The Asset-Swap Steam Release Idea
key_stories.summary: Kaze floats the idea of launching a commercial version of RTYI with new IP assets to sidestep Nintendo rights and reach casual players via Steam.
key_stories.challenge: Cannot legally sell Mario IP or expect mainstream users to patch ROMs.
key_stories.process: Discusses Wiseguy’s Recomp, new plant protagonist, movement tweaks, marketing advantages, gauges chat interest.
key_stories.outcome: Still hypothetical; he will ‘see if there’s interest’.
key_stories.key_quote: If we just put it on Steam and you can get it for like five bucks, then easy.

key_stories.title: Building the Warp Platform
key_stories.summary: Needs a flashy teleport pad but enabling model transparency breaks materials. He invents a solution: scale Mario into the ground, add underside lighting, and disable transparency, achieving the effect without performance cost.
key_stories.challenge: Transparency on Mario’s model conflicts with custom materials.
key_stories.process: Removed transparency flag, manipulated transformation matrix, added point light, tuned animation timing.
key_stories.outcome: A functioning, stylish warp pad now part of Course 15.
key_stories.key_quote: Applying scale animation where Mario just scales into the ground… now it looks really good.
